sub_topic: Finding eigenvalues and eigenvectors of a matrix using power iteration method
message_2:
To perform the power iteration method, we will follow these steps:

1. Choose an initial guess vector x0.
2. Compute the matrix-vector product Ax.
3. Normalize the resulting vector.
4. Repeat steps 2 and 3 for a certain number of iterations.
5. The dominant eigenvalue is approximated by the Rayleigh quotient, and the eigenvector is the normalized vector obtained in the last iteration.

We are given the matrix A and the initial guess vector x0:

A = [1, 2, 3;
     2, 3, 4;
     3, 4, 5]

x0 = [1; 1; 1]

Now, we will perform 5 iterations of the power iteration method.

Iteration 1:
x1 = Ax0 = [6; 9; 12]
Normalized x1 = x1 / ||x1|| = [6/21; 9/21; 12/21] = [2/7; 3/7; 4/7]

Iteration 2:
x2 = Ax1 = [20/7; 30/7; 40/7]
Normalized x2 = x2 / ||x2|| = [20/70; 30/70; 40/70] = [2/7; 3/7; 4/7]

Iteration 3:
x3 = Ax2 = [20/7; 30/7; 40/7]
Normalized x3 = x3 / ||x3|| = [20/70; 30/70; 40/70] = [2/7; 3/7; 4/7]

Iteration 4:
x4 = Ax3 = [20/7; 30/7; 40/7]
Normalized x4 = x4 / ||x4|| = [20/70; 30/70; 40/70] = [2/7; 3/7; 4/7]

Iteration 5:
x5 = Ax4 = [20/7; 30/7; 40/7]
Normalized x5 = x5 / ||x5|| = [20/70; 30/70; 40/70] = [2/7; 3/7; 4/7]

After 5 iterations, the eigenvector approximation is x5 = [2/7; 3/7; 4/7].

Now, we will compute the dominant eigenvalue using the Rayleigh quotient:

Eigenvalue = (x5^T * A * x5) / (x5^T * x5)

Eigenvalue = ([2/7, 3/7, 4/7] * A * [2/7; 3/7; 4/7]) / ([2/7, 3/7, 4/7] * [2/7; 3/7; 4/7])

Eigenvalue = (90/49) / (29/49) = 90/29 â‰ˆ 3.1034

So, the dominant eigenvalue is approximately 3.1034, and its corresponding eigenvector is [2/7; 3/7; 4/7].
